div.p: ANTONIO: The risks for lifestyle-related health problems can be divided into two categories: risk we can change, and risk we cannot change. We deal with both types of risk every day.
ANTONIO: Right now, the sun is shining...
ANTONIO: But the forecast calls for rain. And unfortunately, I cannot control the weather. But if I choose to carry an umbrella...
ANTONIO: I can avoid getting wet. That's a risk I can change. On the other hand, I can't avoid the posibility of lighting striking my umbrella or the wind blowing it away.
ANTONIO: To get a better idea how this applies to heart disease... we're going to get some help from a doctor.
ANTONIO: I'm with Dr. Virginia Colliver, a cardiologist and representative for the American Heart Association. Dr. Colliver, thank you for joining us.
DR. COLLIVER: Thank you for having me. Please step on the treadmill.
ANTONIO: Sure. So Dr. Colliver, since heart disease is a lifestyle-related health problem, are there things we can all do to reduce our risk for developing it?
DR. COLLIVER: Sure many of the risk factors for heart disease are controllable.
ANTONIO: For example, I can control what I eat every day...
DR. COLLIVER: Right, that's one of them. But there are many things you can do to prevent or decrease your chances of developing heart disease and having a heart attack.
DR. COLLIVER: Here at the American Heart Association we publish a list of cardiac-related risks. Some of them you can control and others you can't.
ANTONIO: Interesting, I wonder which risks our learners think they can control?
